be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA AND HOMER.
div.p: Some most intersstiog qnestions as to the editing of the Homeric text at Alexandria are dealt with in Messrs, (renfall and. Hant's recently published work on the Hikes pepyras, and the conclosionis that the final edition of the Homeric text Waa made at Alexandria. Alexandria thas bas a double relation to the great epics, for the author or authors of the Odyssey had ovident'y am seq gnintance, par- sonal or oral, with the snug, little harbour of Rasel-Tin. The episode of Protens in the fourth book clearly showahow frequanted was the isle of Pharos in the earliest dawn of the Greek era by mariners from tha Aigean, who desired to make Aboukir and the Canopio mouth of the 'Nile, and its safe harboar aod the good spring water obtaicable at Ras el-Tin were renowned ia those early days of Mediterranean navigation. The debt of gratitede which Alexandria owed to the Odyssey was amply repaid, for it wae here that the-text waa finally edited with sornpalons care by the grost Alexandria aritios. Bier since a acrap of early Homeric text in the Petrie papyri showed large divergences from onr valgate, it was first suspected and than maintained that up to the critical revision by the Alexandrian librarians Homer was in a yery flaid condition, and was read or recited feom very varying texts. In all our fragmente subsequent to the time of Aristarchas, on the contrary, there is great conformity, and the text may be regarded ss anthoritatively settled. This view was strongly combated by Prof. Ludwich, who considers the papyras fragments as merely vnsathorizsd ipaconrate texts, departing id many details from a text already redeived and known in the furttr century B.0. The sdditional evidence brought to bear on this question in> Messrs, Grenfell and Hunt's new volame, and bed with great skill and |, still greater moderation by the authors, ahows. that if tho Alexan irian oritioa were not actomly | the first to fix the text, they mast sarely have |. exerted a strong inflaence in making one of | the older versions, or tha better of. the old |. versions, prevail over the reat.

The "Atheneim" in ite notice of the work says:— We will iflostrate this from an experience we had years ago at Spurggon's Tabsroacle. The great.presober, desiring a fow minutes' rest, called apon the people to ebmke.| ap s hymn. Furtbwith divere parties io divets parts of the charch began to sing, and for some moments there was a wonderfal Babel of oon flicting tanas, Bat presently the best singsra of the best hyar prevailed'; the varying versions or tunes died onty and the whole congregation joined in one vaet urison of sound. More especially the Alexandrian oritios gob—tid of many onnecessary or saperfiuony lines, which oooarred in their proper coshexion olsewhare. We sgreo with every word wf Masara. Grenfell and Hunt's argument, except that we skoald ba disposed to stata it more strongly, and empher'z) the infloenoe of the great oritios in parifying the Homerio text, as it was handed down to the Middle Agas. The famoas Codex Ventas Mar: cianus A (of the tenth ogatary) oontains » better text than any of the early fragments, not becaure it representa an older tradition, bat because it was prapareid by competent critical acholars, probably by Aristarchag.

div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

He declares that inqairies icstitated by himself smoanst' Roropean residents pro- duced 200 replies all sgreeing in repre senting, the position in the interior as being of the most alsrming charso'er, owing to the bostility of the natives Ho informs his readers that the "Lows" owes its origin to the direot i: floence of Constantinople, reminding os that Mostaphs Kamel's title of Pash' originated, not with the Khedive, bot 'with the Baltan, aod adding thet the entrance , of the "Lews" is striotly forbidden by tho Prench Government both in Algeria and Tunis He cotisiders thet the formula of "Bzypt for the Egyptians". hss bean replaced by ' Egypt for the Tarke,"'snd manif-otly regards Mostaphs Pasha, Kamel. 61 «simple agent of tho Ports \ ahd big attitade 'of "Egyptian Patriot" ass dishonest masquerade. Finally, in reply to the Pasha's vehement seseveration that reli gious fanaticism is entirely non-existent in , Baypt oor writer answers; -*Voilk qui parsit positif surtout & qui ne oonnsit point Mustapha Pachs Kamel; par malbeor, il y « longtemps qa'en Egypte il ne re troave plas on seal mem- bre des colonies earopéennes poor croire sur psrole Mustapha Pasha Kamel,

Now, Sir, with every daferencs to Lord Cro mor — in ad@inistrétion of whos) marvellous work ia Bgypt I yieldto none—I ask,Is it right thst.s Presa whoee action is thas correotly described by. the independent Preach writer should be permitted to continas to poison the minds of the anedacated masses here} With what commendab's energy would his lordship esuse to be dismissad any teachers in the native schools convicted of inculoating evil s counsels in the minds of the children onder their care; and yet what bot children in intelligence snd edacation are the fe!labeou of Bgypt? Hove they not an equal right to ® similar 'protection! Is it not an almost grote' 76 perversion of language to aay that it is "the liberty of the Press" which necessitates such livence beiag given to these nnssrqpulous writers to perbspa again lead the poor ignorant peassnt to the gallows for another insane attack apon his best friends or perbaps for] some still' graver movement} Moreover, in Sir P, Le'y's letter appesring in your isane of the 14th iost,, he ssys, writing of India, 'the modern ligavee of the Press awakens not 10 moch gratitade for fee speech as a sort of contempt for ralera that allow themselves to be smitten ia the f.08," and such is precisely the case in this country

The Alexsniriin "Ezyptian Gazette," ander date of yesterday, ainoances the proximate publication of a book by Mr.W. 8. Blant, to be called "Atrocities of Jastios ander British Rale in Bzypt." If this be reslly the reprebeosibla, and | will sey even abominable, title to be attached to the volame, it will bs another tramp-eard io the bands of the Nationalists, who will carefally. cause it to be translated into Arabic. aod present it to the native pablic with exaggerated ealogies of the anthor, and this in order to disoredit as mach as possible the loosl Britieh administration. A new joarnal belonging to the National party hss msde its sppearance onder ths name of the "Minbar," or 'Palpit,", whose opening statement that sithoogh holding high ite daties to i's yountry, Bgypt, it holds still higher its duties ro its probable futore tone—s dangeroas one. it is now engaged in attacking Lord Cromer, snd discusses bis probable recall with « wealth of inventive faculty folly qualitying the joar- na! even thos early to proudly claim eqoslity on the spore of yeraci'y with ths "Laws" teelf. Ia my Opinion the number of Britich voldiers in Bgypt is quite insufficient to deal rith any important distarbanoes criginatiog n fa! m,-for theo both ths fellabeen roups aod police would {ail us, tho large aropean popalation on the Sars Canal and| o the interior of the country is entirely with-| jut-protection, the reanty British force being livided between Cairo and Alexandria, whorg Ley sppoar tobe secladed as mach as possiblo | om the patio gazs, donbtlers ont of conai- eration for native feeling, and this I think be a mistake

In conclasion. -In s Jesd'ng article upon PaoJslamism the "Temps" compares the established position of France in Algeria with the mach loover one of Great Britain in Egypt, and ssys:—"Io Egypt the British occupation is purely military and administrative. The dreem of ehsking it off presents no such 'absolate impossibility as need prevent men of edocation indolging in it" 5 very wise reflection on the part cf am emivent and friendly foreign joarnal which I commend with every sentiment of respect to the serious con- sideration of his Majesty's Government.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM IN EGYPT.
div.p: If s fear ago any one of lessmathority than Lord Cromer had ventored to snggest that in Egypt of all cotntries the Pan Islamic seed had fallen on to fraitful soil, "the man in the street" bere would have Iaoghed him to scorn. "What? In Egypt, in a conntry which wo have reseord from oppression and bank raptoy, to which we have given justice, necurity, prosperity, where we have brought life-giving water to the fields of the poorest fellak, and made the desert to blossom and bear frait,—yoa 'woold have as believe that the people, forgetfol of ell these blessings, which they owe to ocr beneficent rale, are listening once more to the wiles of the unspeakable Tork, who lashed them with whips and scoorged thein with scorpions | And on what groonds ! Simply becaose they happen to be Mosalmana and wo to be Christians | Do we interfere with their creed! Have we closed their morqnes} Have we hampered the pilgrimages to their holy places 1" To the atilitarian logic of the West the immemoris! answer of the Mahomedan East has baen conveyed inthe letter addressed to Lord Cromer by an anonymona correspondent, who sets forth tha views which "predominate in the minds of a considerable number | Rgyptian Moslems," No morg illuminating docamert oan be quoted. for it explains not only the Mabomedan attitade of mind apge which "Abdel Hamid relies to build op Pao Islamism, bat the purpose which shapes! hi action in challenging from time to time, witk what seems at first sight soch wanton temority the open hostility of Christendom.

Yet between the contioaance of tho bene fita which he 80 fresly admits to bavg beer the resalt of British intervention and bis allogianca t» the Khalif thongh it involv the recurrence of the old evils, of which he at least ba not forgotten the reality, bis choice is made as soon ss he is compelle: to choose. Here we have the real olve te Abdol Hamid's aotion. Many people in Buglanc Jand not only in Bogland bat all over Barope asked themselves in vain, doring the reoen' controversy between this conatry and Tarkey why the Sulten shoald inoar the risk of ar armed conflict with the British Empire tor the eake of a remote strip of dosert, Th: apparent cacse as no doubt inadeqrate ; bo the apparent cause was not the real canse Pan-Ielam'sm proaches disaffastion to evory form of alien ard non Mshomedan role; ii appeals to every grievsnce, legitimate or ille gitimste, which an sliex or. non-Mahomatns role inevitably oalls forth ; it teaches evary Moslem to tara towards tha Kholf for holy and redress, But the saprema asanotion o Islam is, and his always beao, the eword and, to serve the parposes af Pan Islamism, to convert diastirotion ioto an active and aggressive foro», the world of Islam mast be brought once more to balieve that the Khalif can and will, in his own good time once more wield in its defence the ever viotorions sword of Islam. The Pan-Islami Press in Cairo hastened daring the recen crisis to welcome the advent of the Turkial army which was to liberate the valley .o the Nile, and one paper wert so fa even as to snnonnce that Tarkish troop wore already landing in Alexandrit. To as al '| this eeems child'ss enongh, and in the fina ontcome of the origia we re only a fresh sell inflicted bomilistion forthe Sultan. It ms: well be doabted, navertholess, whether that i || the cosstraction which will be generally place Jopon these matters in the Bast. How easy iti || to confase the immediate issuer, or to explair them away as another proof of the Khalit' infinite wisdom. The completion of a farthe section of the railway to Mecca is alread: described as Turkey's anawor to British thrante Abdal Hamid, it is argued, was too profound); solicitous of the welfare of Islam to imperil thi safety of the Holy Places until he had carrie out in its entirety the great rcheme which wil plsce them beyond the reach of British design Theo in his own good time will the Khali draw the scifpitar Uf action, and cast away th soabbard of reflection. In the meantime let al good Moslems gird up their loina to be read; '| "to leap ap at bis call."(Blackws6d's Magazine.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON SEED IN. INDIA.
div.p: Experiments in tbe caltivation of Bgyptian { cotton in Bind have been in progress for some time, but the results did not become definitely known until the other day, when the Govern ment of Bombay igued a Report on the sabjoct by the Director of Agricaltare. The Report (says the "Stateman,") may be desoribed as high'y satisfactory. The scocess of the crop in 1904 was so remarkable that, althoagh the Board of Agrioultare insisted that the cultiva- tion mast be regarded as parely experimedtal, it was decided to import ten tons of Bgyptian seed and to distribute it amongst the oultive- tors, With this imported seed, and the seed obtained from the previous year's crop, 1,500 sores in all were placed under cotton. These results are all the more noteworthy beosose Sind, anlike Egypt, has no perennial stpply of water. In fact the only season suitable to cotton haz been found to be from March to November, This fact limits the onltivation to the small reas served by perennial canale ; for no inun- dation oanals are able to supply water before May. Another difficulty that tends to retard fhe development of cotton-growing is the dis- posal of the produce. This question has been the subject of anxiona consideration. It was anticipated that the loca: "banias," or middle- men, would refase to deal with the i to their want of knowledge cf the val atap'o, and this anticipation was fully jastified by the event. At the same time, through an excess of official oaction it) was considered inadvisable that the Government shoald, even in these special ciroumstances, enter into com- petition with private trade by making direot purchases. In this dilemmas the sathorities applied to certain large firms at Karachi which desl im cotton; bat even there appeared relactant to make the special arrangements necessary for the disposal. of 20 small a crop soattered overs large area with considerable difficulties in the way of inspection and carriage. At Isat, however, one big firm was indoced tf parch available at thd fall themselves only ibe commercial profit.

'Tho renalt was mannds of Absesi seed cotton and 5,400 mannda of Metefifi 'reed cotton were obtained, besides an ouftarn of lint, of 26 9 and 82.8 per cent. respectively, It is noticeable that the auttarns of the latter qaslity oorrespond almost exactly to those of the indigeroos Sind cotton. 'Those of the Absasi, however, are considerably lower, Qa the basis of the sales reported from Liverpool it wanld appese that the caltivators obtained about 60 per cent. of the value of the eatton dolivered in that market, With the greater competition that will be forthooming in the presont season, the cultivators may hope to secure oyen & larger percentage. Bat, as the Report points ont, it mast be recognised that tho expense and troable of organising the collection of this cotton and of making special arrangements to gin if a t presen' don- giderable, and the cost of carriage to Karachi, of freight to Bogland and of sale there have to be daduoted. Yet, with all each deductions, it is cloar (hst the indostry is eminently worth enooursgement.

div.head: THE N-D-L MSHIP COMPANY.
div.p: REPORTED LARGE INCRBASE OF SHARB CAPITAL.

'The direotors of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company have, it is stated, decided | to follow.the example of the Hambarg-Ameri- | can Steamship Company and increare the share capital. At a meeting to be held at the | end of the present month the sharebo'ders will be asked to approve « proposal to make a fresh isaae of shares amounting to £1,250,000. 'The only explanation given for the proposal is that the additional capital is intended to pro- vide for an increase in the namber of steamers, as the floet is no lopger sofficient to deal with the growing (raffio of nearly all the lines. The now shares, which have been taken over by s banking syndicate, will be offered to existing shareholders at the rate of 116 per ont. At present the issoed ahare ospital of the company amoanta to £5,000,000, so that the aogmenta- tion will bring it up to £6,960,000. There are also loans outstanding amounting to £2 768.000.

div.head: EASTERN SHIPPING FREIGHT WAR.
div.p: The freight wat between the German Hansa Steamship Company~and the Pepinsolar and Oriental Company and the British [odia Line coptinues undiminished, and the Boglish com panies are reported to be gaining ground, he Antwerp correspondent of the "Frankfarter 'Ysitong" states that the British India Line proposes to make thirty-two journeys per annum instead of the sixteen journeys hitherto ondertaken. Contracts at the low froight war rates have already teen conoladed ontil the middle snd even as far asthe end of next year. It remains tor the future to decide, the correspondent adda, whether the Hanss Com- pany will continoe ths present low rate or fix common rates in conjanction with the English companies.

div.head: THE NEGRO BRAIN.
div.p: ITS SIZE AND QUALITY.

An article on "The Negro Brain" in the "Contary Magazine," by Dr. RB. Bean, gosa into the question of ths brain stractare of the negro at some length After giving a table of average meascremants, he saya the Agares soggest a probable di noe in the relative power, or capacity, or activity, of) the frontal lobes in the brein of the two, races of 20 per cant. in favour of the Caucasian. This is moch greater in many individoals. Having established the facts (1) that theCavcasian brain is heavier than that of the negro, (2) that the relative qnantity of the white fibre is greater io the Cancasian than in the negro, and (8) that the anterior association centre (front esd of the brain) sod the front end of the ocorpas callosom are larger in the Cavoarian than in the negro. He concludes : — The white and the black races are antipodal, then, in cerdinal points. The one has a large frontal region of the brain, the other a larger region behind ; the ona Is snbjestive, the other objeati the ones great reasoner, the other pre eminently emotional ; ths one domi- neering, bat having great self contral, the other meek and sabmissiye, bat violent and lacking self-con}ral when the passions are aronred ; the one s very advanced race, the other a very backward one. The Caucasian and the negro are tondamentally opposite extremes in evolation Havieg demonatrated that the nogro and the (acoasian are wildly different in characteristion, due to a deficiency of grey matter and omnect- ing Abres in the negro brain, especially in the .| frontal lobes, a deficlonoy that is hereditary and can be altered only by intermarriage, we are foyoed to conclade that it useless to try to te the negro by edoocation or otherwise, except in the dirgotion of his natoral endow- weuts, 'ke way may be made plain to the black people, and they may be encooraged in the proper direction, bat the solation of the qaeation still must 2. me from within the race Latthem win thoir reward by diligent service.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
